==Romantic ballet== The most successful period for female ballet dancers was around the 1830s and 1840s when they became the great stars of [[Romantic ballet]]. The Italian-Swedish [[Marie Taglioni]] (1804–1884) not only excelled at the Paris Opera when she danced ''[[La Sylphide]]'' in 1832 but extended her fame to Saint Petersburg's [[Mariinsky Ballet]] as well as to the stages of Berlin, Milan and London until her retirement in 1847. It was she who developed ballet's [[en pointe]] (dancing on the tips of the toes) while introducing new fashions in dress and hair styling which became popular throughout Europe. The Austrian [[Fanny Elssler]] (1810–1884) gained fame and fortune by dancing the flirtatious Spanish [[cachucha]] in ''Le Diable boiteux'', performing not only in Austria, Germany, France, England and Russia but also in the United States. Nevertheless, in 1845 she refused to dance with her rivals Marie Taglioni, [[Carlotta Grisi]], [[Fanny Cerrito]], and [[Lucile Grahn]] in [[Jules Perrot]]'s ''[[Pas de Quatre]]''.<ref name=vam>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/r/romantic-ballet/|title=Romantic Ballet|publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum|accessdate=16 April 2014|language=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mtholyoke.edu/courses/nvaget/danseuse/ladanseuse/ladanseuse/1830-1848.html|title=La Danseuse: Evolution et Révolution: Les années 1830 à 1848:La danse romantique|publisher=Mount Holyoke|accessdate=16 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
Presented at [[Her Majesty's Theatre]] in London, the ''Pas de Quatre'' caused a sensation, bringing together the four greatest ballerinas of the day. In addition to Marie Taglioni, Italy's Grisi (1819–1899) had become famous both in Paris and Saint Petersburg for her ''[[Giselle]]'', while Cerrito from Naples had become the star of [[La Scala]] in Milan. Grahn (1819–1907), a Dane trained by Bournonville, was based in Paris but had also danced in London, Saint Petersburg and Milan before settling in Germany.<ref name=vam/>
<gallery class="center"> File:Marie-taglioni-in-zephire.jpg|[[Marie Taglioni]] in ''Zephire et Flore'' (c. 1831) File:Elssler Cachucha.jpg|[[Fanny Elssler]] in ''La Cachucha'' (1836) File:Giselle -Carlotta Grisi -1841 -2.jpg|[[Carlotta Grisi]] in ''Giselle'' (1841) File:Vivandiere -Kathi -Fanny Cerrito -London -1844.jpg|[[Fanny Cerrito]] in ''La Vivandière'' (1844) File:Lucille grahn.jpg|[[Lucile Grahn]] in ''La Cachucha'' (1838) File:Pauline Leroux in François Benoist's Le Diable amoureux.jpg|[[Pauline Leroux]] in ''[[Le Diable amoureux (ballet)|Le Diable Amoureux]]'' (1840) </gallery>
Several notable Italian ballerinas emerged in the second half of the 19th century, reaching their zeniths in Russia. Italian-born [[Virginia Zucchi]] (1849–1933) first danced in Italy and Germany but her interpretations of [[Marius Petipa]]'s ballet in Russia were so successful that the Tzar insisted she should join the [[Mariinsky Ballet]] in Saint Petersburg. In the mid-1880s, she starred in ''[[Coppélia]]'', ''[[La fille mal gardée]]'' and ''[[La Esmeralda (ballet)|La Esmeralda]]'', revolutionizing ballet in Russia through the extraordinary power of her performances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803133549548|title=Virginia Zucchi|publisher=Oxford Index|accessdate=17 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Pierina Legnani]] (1863–1930) from Milan followed as similar path, also dancing at the Mariinsky from 1892 where she originated famous roles in Petipa's ballets including ''[[Cinderella (Fitinhof-Schell)|Cinderella]]'', ''[[Swan Lake]]'' and ''[[Raymonda]]'', gaining the title of [[prima ballerina assoluta]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100058642|title=Pierina Legnani|publisher=Oxford Reference|accessdate=17 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Carlotta Brianza]] (1867–1930), also from Milan, first gained fame at [[La Scala]] with which she toured the United States. She is remembered above all for dancing Aurora at the premiere of Petipa's ''[[The Sleeping Beauty (ballet)|Sleeping Beauty]]'' in 1890.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oxfordindex.oup.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095526796|title=Carlotta Brianza|publisher=Oxford Index|accessdate=17 April 2014 |language=}}</ref><ref name="PraaghBrinson1963">{{cite book|last1=Praagh|first1=Peggy Van|last2=Brinson|first2=Peter|title=The choreographic art: an outline of its principles and craft|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g7I3AQAAIAAJ|year=1963|publisher=Knopf}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Esmeralda -Virginia Zucchi -1886.JPG|[[Virginia Zucchi]] in ''La Esmeralda'' (1886) File:Legnani-whitepearl.jpg|[[Pierina Legnani]] in ''La Perle'' (1896) File:Brianza-Esmeralda.jpg|[[Carlotta Brianza]] in ''La Esmeralda'' (c. 1890) </gallery>
==20th-century ballet== New, more dynamic approaches to ballet developed from the beginning of the 20th century, the most influential being [[Sergei Diaghilev]]'s [[Ballets Russes]], promoting innovative collaborations between choreographers, composers and dancers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history-and-heritage/ART309940|title= Diaghilev's Golden Age of the Ballets Russes dazzles London with V&A display|author=Kirstie Brewer|publisher=Culture24|date=13 October 2010|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> One of the early stars was [[Anna Pavlova]] (1881–1931) who gained fame by dancing ''[[The Dying Swan]]'' choreographed by [[Mikhail Fokine]] before joining the Ballets Russes in 1909.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russianballethistory.com/annapavlovathelegend.htm|title=The Legendary Anna Pavlova|publisher=Russian Ballet History|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Her rival, [[Tamara Karsavina]] (1885–1978), who also performed with the Ballets Russes, is remembered above all for creating the title role in Fokine's ''[[The Firebird]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.russianballethistory.com/diaghilevsdancers.htm|title=Diaghilev's dancers|publisher=Russian Ballet History|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Olga Spessivtseva]] (1895–1991) danced with the Mariinsky in Saint Petersburg but also toured with the Ballets Russes, dancing Aurora in Diaghilev's ''The Sleeping Princess'' (1921) in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://etoiledelopera.e-monsite.com/pages/etoile-femme-de-1900-a-1929/olga-spessivtseva.html|title=Olga Spessivtseva |publisher=Les étoiles de l'Opéra de Paris|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Anna Pavlova 1912.jpg|[[Anna Pavlova]] (1912) File:Tamara Karsavina Petrushka 1911.jpg|[[Tamara Karsavina]] (1911) File:Olga Spessiva in Swan Lake costume, 1934 photographer Sydney Fox Studio, 3rd Floor, 88 King St, Sydney.jpg|[[Olga Spessivtseva]] (1934) </gallery>
Ballet also began to develop in London, thanks mainly to the efforts of two women. Polish-born [[Marie Rambert]] (1888–1982) who had also gained experience with the Ballets Russes founded the [[Ballet Club]] (later the Rambert Dance Company) in 1926 introducing new choreographers such as [[Frederick Ashton]]. Even more influential, [[Ninette de Valois]] (1898–2001) spent three years with the Ballets Russes before creating London's [[Vic-Wells Ballet]] in 1931 (later becoming the Royal Ballet) where [[Alicia Markova]] (1910–2004) was the first prima ballerina, starring in ballets from the Mariinsky's classical productions. Markova left to form her own touring company in 1937. Ten years later [[Margot Fonteyn]] (1919–1991) became the company's prima ballerina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/content/articles/e/establishment-of-british-ballet/|title=The Establishment of British Ballet|publisher=V&A|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> The height of her fame came in 1961 when she embarked on a partnership with [[Rudolf Nureyev]], first in ''[[Giselle]]'', until she retired in 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nureyev.org/rudolf-nureyev-biography-margot-fonteyn/|title=Rudolf Nureyev and Margot Fonteyn, the perfect partnership|publisher=Rudolf Nureyev Foundation|accessdate=23 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Ballet Goes To the Factory- Dance and Entertainment Organised by the Council For the Encouragement of Music and the Arts, England, 1943 D14038.jpg|[[Marie Rambert]], centre (1943) File:Ninette de Valois, 1914.jpg|[[Ninette de Valois]] (1914) File:Alicia Markova.jpg|[[Alicia Markova]] (1940) File:Margot Fonteyn Cinderella 1957.jpg|[[Margot Fonteyn]] (1957) </gallery>
As ballet developed in the United States, [[Maria Tallchief]] (1925–2013), the first major American prima ballerina, was promoted by the choreographer [[Bronislava Nijinska]] (1891–1972) when she joined the [[Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo]] in New York in 1942. She danced as a soloist in [[George Balanchine]]'s arrangements for ''[[Song of Norway]]'' in 1944. As Balanchine's wife, she soon became the star of the [[New York City Ballet]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/13/arts/dance/maria-tallchief-brilliant-ballerina-dies-at-88.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|title=Maria Tallchief, a Dazzling Ballerina and Muse for Balanchine, Dies at 88|author=Jack Anderson|newspaper=New York Times|date=12 April 2013|accessdate=24 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Lucia Chase]] (1897–1986) was a co-founder of the [[American Ballet Theatre]] in 1939 and became its artistic director for over 40 years, overseeing the production of a wide variety of new ballets.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/01/19/arts/dance-view-lucia-chase-helped-create-the-ballet-world-we-know.html|title=Dance View: Lucia Chase Helped Create the Ballet World we Know|author=Anna Kisselgoff|newspaper=New York Times|date=19 January 1986|accessdate=24 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Several outstanding American ballerinas have emerged over the years including [[Gelsey Kirkland]] (born 1952), who performed the leading role in ''[[The Firebird]]'' when she was just 17,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/gelsey-kirkland-9365803#controversy-and-comeback&awesm=~oCmUgMJASHMm00|title=Gelsey Kirkland|publisher=Biography.com|accessdate=24 April 2014|language=}}</ref> and [[Suzanne Farrell]] (born 1945) who was the star of Balanchine's ''[[Don Quixote (ballet)|Don Quixote]]'' in 1965.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.achievement.org/autodoc/page/far0bio-1|title=Suzanne Farrell Biography|publisher=Academy of Achievement|accessdate=24 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo Nutcracker 1940.JPG|[[Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo]], ''Nutcracker'' (1940) File:Maria Tallchief 1954.png|[[Maria Tallchief]] (1954) File:Suzanne Farrell 1965.jpg|[[Suzanne Farrell]] (1965) </gallery>
==Other forms of dance== [[File:Flamenco dancer 3467.jpg|thumb|200px|Flamenco dancer]] Women have also contributed significantly to most other forms of dance, in particular [[flamenco]], [[modern dance]], [[expressionist dance]], [[belly dance]] and [[cabaret]] which led to [[musical theatre]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artsalive.ca/en/dan/dance101/forms.asp|title=Dance Forms: An Introduction |publisher=ArtsAlive.ca|accessdate=17 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
===Flamenco=== Flamenco music originated in the south of Spain in the 15th century, probably resulting from the influence of the Moors with possible origins in India. While many of the singers who emerged in the 18th century were men, women increasingly gained fame as dancers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andalucia.org/es/flamenco/evolucion-etapa-hermetica-primeros-cantaores/|title=Flamenco: Evolución. Etapa Hermética. Primeros cantaores|publisher=Andalucía.org|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=Spanish}}</ref> One of the earliest was [[Juana la Macarrona]] (1860–1947) who first performed in Seville with singer [[Silverio Franconetti]] but soon become popular not only throughout Spain but across Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nyoflamenco.es/index.php/aula-flamenca/artistas/baile/509-la-macarrona|title=La Macarrona|publisher=Noticias y Ocio|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=Spanish}}</ref> [[Lola Flores]] (1923–1995) is remembered for singing and dancing Andalusian folklore, especially flamenco, [[copla (music)|copla]] and [[chotis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.andalucia.com/history/people/lolaflores.htm|title=Lola Flores|publisher=Andalucia.com|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Angelita Vargas]] (born 1946) is considered to be one of the greatest stars of Andalusian flamenco dancing, touring Europe, the United States, Japan and Australia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apsaraflamenco.fr/Angelita-Vargas.html?lang=fr|title=Angelita Vargas|publisher=Apsâra Flamenco|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
===Modern dance=== Led by women, various styles of [[modern dance]] began to develop towards the end of the 19th century. [[Loie Fuller]] (1862–1928) from Chicago was one of the pioneers. She employed her own natural approach to movement and improvisation, later becoming a star at the [[Folies Bergères]] in Paris.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://artsalive.ca/en/dan/meet/bios/artistDetail.asp?artistID=168|title=Loie Fuller|publisher=Dance: National Arts Centre|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Inspired by Greek art, [[Isadora Duncan]] (1877–1927) from San Francisco paved the way to the modern free dance style believing it was more important to express the essence of life through movement rather than to follow the precepts of classical ballet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mdc.edu/wolfson/academic/ArtsLetters/art_philosophy/Humanities/beginnings/beginnings_of_modern_dance.htm|title=The Beginnings of Modern Dance|publisher=Miami Dade College|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Raised on a farm in New Jersey, [[Ruth St. Denis]] (1879–1968) developed her own interpretations of Oriental dance as an expression of spiritualism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.danceheritage.org/treasures/stdenis_essay_hecht.pdf|title=Ruth St. Denis (1879—1968): America's Divine Dancer |publisher=Dance Heritage Coalition|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> The American [[Martha Graham]] (1894–1991) exerted considerable influence on the development of modern dance through her New York-based [[Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803095902861|title=Martha Graham|publisher=Oxford Reference|accessdate=20 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Other female figures who contributed to developments in the mid-20th century include [[Doris Humphrey]] (1895–1958) who choreographed Afro-American spirituals and [[Helen Tamiris]] (1905–1966) who played an important part in choreographing early musicals.<ref name="HendersonStacey2014">{{cite book|last1=Henderson|first1=Lol|last2=Stacey|first2=Lee|title=Encyclopedia of Music in the 20th Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=m8W2AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA41|year=2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-92946-6|pages=41–}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/tamiris-helen|title=Helen Tamaris|author=Pauline Tish|publisher=Jewish Women's Archive|accessdate=20 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Another major choreographer of Broadway musicals was German-born [[Hanya Holm]] (1893–1992), a student of Mary Wigman.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/11/04/theater/hanya-holm-is-dead-at-99-influential-choreographer.html|title=Hanya Holm Is Dead at 99; Influential Choreographer|author=Jennifer Dunning|newspaper=New York Times|date=4 November 1992|accessdate=20 April 2014|language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Loie Fuller cph.3b32370.jpg|[[Loie Fuller]] (1896) File:Isadora Duncan 1903.jpg|[[Isadora Duncan]] (1903) File:Ruth St. Denis in Black and Gold Nautch (Hartsook Photo).jpg|[[Ruth St. Denis]] (1916) File:Martha Graham 1948.jpg|[[Martha Graham]] (1948) </gallery>
===Expressionist dance=== The German [[Mary Wigman]] is credited as the creator of [[expressionist dance]]. Inspired by Oriental percussion, she often stressed the macabre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://theatre-dance.cahss.ualr.edu/waynesweb/Expressionism/ExpressionisticDance.htm|title=Expressionistic Dance: Mary Wigman|publisher=Twentieth Century Dance|accessdate=18 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> [[Hertha Feist]] (1896–1990), also from Germany, was an expressionist dancer and choreographer. She established her own school in Berlin, combining gymnastics with nudism and dance although her ambitions were later seriously curtailed by the Nazis.<ref name=fmp>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-kultur.de/tanz/feist2.htm|title=Feist|author=Frank-Manuel Peter|publisher=SK Stiftung Kultur|accessdate=19 February 2014 |language=German}}</ref> Also an associate of Wigman, [[Gret Palucca]] (1902–1993) opened her own schools in Germany in the 1920s and 1930s but they were later closed because of her Jewish ancestry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adk.de/de/archiv/archivbestand/darstellende-kunst/kuenstler/Gret_Palucca.htm|title=Gret Palucca|publisher=Akademie der Künste|accessdate=19 April 2014 |language=German}}</ref> One of her students, [[Dore Hoyer]] (1911–1967), who was also an associate of Mary Wigman, developed her own programmes before the [[Second World War]] in Germany, the Netherlands, Denmark and Sweden. After the war she became ballet director at the [[Hamburg State Opera]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sk-kultur.de/tanz/hoyer.htm|title=Dore Hoyer (1911-1967)|publisher=SK Stiftung Kultur|accessdate=19 April 2014 |language=German}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-P047336, Berlin, Mary Wigman-Studio.jpg|[[Mary Wigman]] (1959) File:Genja Jonas - Gret Palucca 1930er-Jahre.jpg|[[Gret Palucca]] (1930s) File:Hoyer, Dore.jpg|[[Dore Hoyer]] </gallery>
===Belly dance=== While belly dancing appears to have its origins in the distant past, it was introduced to Europe and North America towards the end of the 19th century. Several of Egypt's film actresses performed belly dancing in the musicals of the 1930s and 1940s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aleenah.com/history.html|title=Bellydance Unveiled: A Brief History|publisher=Aleenah.com|accessdate=20 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> Early stars included [[Tahia Carioca]] (1919–1999), [[Samia Gamal]] (1924–1994) and [[Nelly Mazloum]] (1929–2003).<ref name="Hammond2007">{{cite book|last=Hammond|first=Andrew|title=Popular Culture in the Arab World: Arts, Politics, and the Media|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O06bOHRW7s8C&pg=PA192|year=2007|publisher=American Univ in Cairo Press|isbn=978-977-416-054-7|pages=192–}}</ref> From the 1960s, belly dance became increasingly popular across the United States with stars including [[Dalilah (bellydancer)]] (1936–2001), Dahlena and [[Serena Wilson|Serena]] (1933–2007).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bellydance.org/articles/bellydance_history.html|title=Belly Dance History ~ An American Odessey: A History of Modern US Bellydance|author=Helen Waldie|publisher=IAMED|accessdate=20 April 2014 |language=}}</ref>
<gallery class="center"> File:Egyptian dancing girl.jpg|Egyptian belly dancer, [[World's Columbian Exposition|Chicago World Fair]] (1893) File:Tahyea05.jpg|[[Tahia Carioca]] (1920) File:Dalilah bailando danza oriental con crótalos.jpg|[[Dalilah (bellydancer)]] (1963) File:Randa Kamel Egyptian Bellydancer 2007 1.jpg|Randa Kamel, Cairo (2007) File:Rachel Brice 1 DSC 0126.jpeg|[[Rachel Brice]], Rennes (2012) </gallery>
===Cabaret=== Women started to sing and dance in the cabarets of Paris in the 1890s, emphasizing the female body by introducing seductive movements highlighting their breasts and hips. Most of them had no formal training, the exception being [[Cléo de Mérode]] (1875–1966) who left the Paris Opera to perform at the [[Folies Bergère]].<ref name=be>{{cite web|url=https://www.mtholyoke.edu/courses/nvaget/danseuse/ladanseuse/ladanseuse/1890-1914.html|title=La Danseuse: Evolution et Révolution: Les années 1890 à 1914: La Belle Epoque|publisher=Mount Holyoke|accessdate=21 April 2014 |language=}}</ref> The major choreographer was Algerian-born [[Mariquita (dancer)|Mariquita]] (1830–1922) who became ballet director at the Folies Bergère and the [[Opéra Comique]]. Stars of the period included the Spanish [[La Belle Otero]] from [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] who gained fame at Charles Franconi's [[Cirque d'été]] in 1890,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.histoire-image.org/site/etude_comp/etude_comp_detail.php?i=1140|title=La Belle Otero, emblème de la Belle Époque|publisher=Histoire par l'image|accessdate=21 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref> [[Émilienne d’Alençon]] (1869–1946) who danced at the Folies Bergère, and Dutch-born [[Mata Hari]] (1876–1917) who from 1905 became famous for her Indonesian-inspired temple dance, first in Paris and then in other European capitals.<ref name=be/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biography.com/people/mata-hari-9402348#exotic-dancer-and-mistress&awesm=~oCbYeBl3Wuhvzz|title=Mata Hari: Spy, Dancer (1876–1917)|publisher=bio.|accessdate=22 April 2014|language=}}</ref> [[La Goulue]] (1866–1929) is remembered for dancing the [[cancan]] at the [[Moulin Rouge]] in the 1890s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.appl-lachaise.net/appl/article.php3?id_article=1955|title=Weber Louise, dit La Goulue (1866-1929)|publisher=Amis et Passionnés du Père-Lachaise|accessdate=22 April 2014 |language=French}}</ref>
